channel.title: [317] Not accepting any incoming connections (yes, I've port forwarded)
channel.description: I used to run a few servers about a year or two ago. I decided to start another one up, but I can't accept any incoming connections. I've port forwarded, gotten my DNS, and allowed the port in my firewall. I know it's not my firewall because I can't connect to my server with my firewall off, either. I can connect using local host (127.0.0.1), but when I try to connect using my DNS or IP it doesn't go through. Does anyone have an ideas why? Any idea may be useful. I'm running Windows 7 64 bit, and a 317 allstar.

item.title: [317] Not accepting any incoming connections (yes, I've port forwarded)
item.dc:creator: @Pker_DX Pker DX
item.description:
@Pker_DX wrote:

[quote=“makiener, post:17, topic:520426”][quote author=Pker DX link=topic=638921.msg4306797#msg4306797 date=1369998250]
Everyones stupid here.
When hosting a server off your MODEM, you must connect through an IPv4/IPv6, NOT your IP. Then, everyone else connects to the No-ip.
[/quote]
Wireless router, actually.

Also; I’ve tried disabling my firewall entirely (even though I’ve allowed incoming and outgoing connections on the port.) Still doesn’t work.[/quote]
It’s the same thing, Modem/Wireless router, so either your doing something wrong or your router is loved up.

Read full topic
item.source: [317] Not accepting any incoming connections (yes, I've port forwarded)

item.title: [317] Not accepting any incoming connections (yes, I've port forwarded)
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“makiener, post:5, topic:520426”]I am absolutely positive I’ve port forwarded correctly. I’ve been doing it for years for various reasons.


Also, I know; but I’m simply trying to connect with my IP rather than local host because I wanted to check if it was online… which it apparently is not.[/quote]

Uh did you port forward on UDP as well??

  • You need both tcp/udp.
    Also, run the server then check your IP on canyouseeme.org.
    it needs to say open.

Read full topic

item.title: [317] Not accepting any incoming connections (yes, I've port forwarded)
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“makiener, post:7, topic:520426”]Why would I remove it? It’s just my local IP assigned by my router.
Also, trust me, I know how to port forward. As I said; I’ve been doing it for years for various reasons and have done so on this router before.[/quote]
Obviously you port forwarded wrong because your port isn’t open.

Read full topic
item.source: [317] Not accepting any incoming connections (yes, I've port forwarded)

item.title: [317] Not accepting any incoming connections (yes, I've port forwarded)
item.dc:creator: @makiener makiener
item.description:
@makiener wrote:

Lol… I don’t think you understand. That’s my local, router assigned IP. It is not my actual IP.
Also, that’s harder than you think. Considering hacking is a hobby of mine, I would know. So long as they have updated software and an updated operating system, chances are nothing is (known to be) exploitable. Even if I did release my actual IP (which you can get from a server’s DNS in a couple of seconds anyways), I have taken many measures to assure my safety.
Thank you for your concern, however. I appreciate it.

Read full topic

item.description:

canyouseeme always says that it can’t connect to any of my ports.
Also, I know for a fact my client is connecting to my IP, and I’m fairly sure there’s no files in my server that I need to change. If there is, I haven’t found it yet.

item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

You didn’t change all the ip’s in your files or you didn’t port forward correctly.

To check if your port is open go to canyouseeme.org\

Good luck
